Description: East Greek terracotta figure vase (plastic vase). Reconstructed from two joined fragments of aryballos in the form of a duck. The duck is represented swimming with head arched back. Tail damaged and spout lost. Mould-made with 'black glaze' slip, applied white (faded) and red paint and incised detail. Head is black with white spots, eyes incised and surrounded with white spots. Wings are black with red and white dots on front part, then a red line, then long line of incisions. The tail is black and the legs red. Orange-brown fine Ionian clay fabric with common very fine mica inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context ΦA (Well 1)
Curator's comments: A parallel is a mid 6th century BC duck vase (BM1889,0521.1) excavated at Kamiros. Closest parallel for the form, but in a different fabric is a duck vase from Kamiros BM1867,0508.866, originally thought to be made in Rhodes (Higgins 1959: 35), but possibly Ionian as per BM1888,0601.752b that has a similar fabric (Jones 1985: 670). Higgins' East Greek classification is confirmed by Jones' NAA analysis of BM1888,0601.659 that places it within his East Greek, possibly Milesian group (Jones 1985: 673). Jones erroneously identifies this as 1888,0601.654. NAA suggests this is the same fabric as GR 1888,0601.605. Jones, R. E. 1985. Greek and Cypriot Pottery: A Review of Scientific Studies. Athens.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (1662)
Gardner 1888 / Naukratis II (p. 58, pl. XIV, no. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.020) (Phase 3)
